Hi Greg, thanks to both you and Colin (in his prior post) for pointing ou=
t his work.  As a non-objective type of behavioral search, it is indeed rem=
iniscent of novelty search.  Like both of you I'm not really sure if the id=
ea is that new, though it's not entirely the same as anything else either. =
 Another question is whether it has any advantage over easier-to-understand=
 ideas like searching for novelty. A couple concepts that remind me a bit o=
f this work outside novelty search include "homeokinesis" (http://robot.inf=
ormatik.uni-leipzig.de/videos/) and "Maximum Entropy Inverse Reinforcement =
Learning" (which at least sounds quite similar) (http://www.aaai.org/Papers=
/AAAI/2008/AAAI08-227.pdf)

Best,

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Greg"=
 <greg_barton@...> wrote:
>
> http://www.insidescience.org/content/physicis=
t-proposes-new-way-think-about-intelligence/987
> 
> From the article: 'Ent=
ropica's intelligent behavior emerges from the "physical process of trying =
to capture as many future histories as possible," said Wissner-Gross.'  
> =

> Fairly close to searching for novelty.
>
